sn48.49:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn48.49:4.3: Now at that time Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja had declared enlightenment:
sn48.49:4.4: “I understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn48.49:4.5: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha,
sn48.49:4.6: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn48.49:4.7: and told him what had happened. Then they said:
sn48.49:5.3: “What reason does Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja see for doing this?”
sn48.49:6.1: “It’s because Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja has developed and cultivated three faculties that he declares enlightenment:
sn48.49:6.2: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’
sn48.49:6.4: The faculties of mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
sn48.49:6.5: It’s because Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja has developed and cultivated these three faculties that he declares enlightenment.
sn48.49:6.7: Whats the culmination of these three faculties?
sn48.49:6.10: Of rebirth, old, age, and death.
sn48.49:6.11: It’s because he sees that they culminate in the ending of rebirth, old age, and death that Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja declares enlightenment:
sn48.49:6.12: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
